fields.description:
Copying SourceTree's diffs to the clipboard has always been possible using cmd-c.  Here's a ticket showing that it was considered a pre-existing feature https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREE-1564  (in comments).

This is broken now.  I cannot copy form the diff.
1.6.17.0

I don't know about others, but this has majorly hampered my workflow.

BTW, how do I downgrade SourceTree?
fields.summary: "Copy to clipboard" from diff not working

fields.description: I can not check the changes made in Mercurial Repository.
fields.summary: I can not check the changes made in Mercurial Repository.

fields.description:
I had a project cloned to let's say C:\Projects\MyProject
For some reason I deleted that directory.
I then opened SourceTree and selected the bookmark which referenced this deleted dir.
I then went to STASH and while SourceTree was still open, I decided to clone MyProject again to the exact same directory name as before.

The cloning successfully finished, and then SourceTree went knock out. It crashed.
fields.summary: Crash when cloning repo to previously erased local directory

fields.description:
After a day of Sourcetree usage, I have loads of orhapned git.exe process in Task Manager.   I don't use anything but Sourcetree, so these must have been started by Sourcetree.

!Untitled.png|thumbnail!

Crash at start

fields.description:
- set ST to use system Git installation.
- open a repo that contains a submodule.
=> submodule not displayed anymore. Then there is a mess that can corrupt a repository for example when changing active branch.

- set ST to use embeddedGit installation.
- open a repo that contains a submodule.
=> submodule is back.

ST version 1.6.17.0
fields.summary: git submodule not anymore detected with system git

I just upgraded to SourceTree 1.6.16 for windows.  I use the system Git with OpenSSH for authentication.  When SourceTree launches, the OpenSSH terminal launches for a split second before closing.  This prevents me from updating or fetching from remotes.

Also, when clicking the toolbar icon for the Terminal, SourceTree crashes.  The log from today is attached.

Seems to be related to trying to find the System Git, as there is no place to specify the Git location.

fields.description:
Upgraded from pre-1.6.15 (probably 1.6.14, but I forget exactly) to 1.6.16, skipping 1.6.15. Upon opening SourceTree, hit the Terminal button. Crash window appears.

Log indicates that SourceTree is looking for ssh-agent in C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\usr\bin\ssh-agent.exe, but it has always been in C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\bin\ssh-agent.exe (note the lack of /usr).

Tried copying necessary files to the requested directory, but it didn't resolve the issue.

Terminal button worked fine before upgrade to 1.6.16.

*Problem*

The problem appears to occur when SourceTree tries to use a v1.9.5 "System Git".
AFAICS using v2.x as "System Git" works, as does using the embedded v1.9.5 

*Work Around*
# use the embedded Git v1.9.5
# use a System Git v2.x

*UPDATE*
Using Git 2.x currently will require the use of Putty rather than OpenSSH.

fields.description: Since there are already some features with Stash integration, it would be great to be able to view any commit in Stash. For example, a user could right click on a commit and select a menu option which would open his browser to the Stash page with that commit similar to how the "Create Pull Request" feature works. The use case for this is that sometimes it is hard to read the commit in the small preview panel, and it's very convenient to be able to link a URL to other people when you want to show them a certain commit. I wrote a custom action hack to use this myself on the "Log/History" view, but it would be awesome if this were a standard product feature and it worked on other panels like the dedicated log/blame windows.

fields.description:
After a recent  git upgrade (2.4 -> 2.4.5) on the remote repo the pre-authentication step throws the following error:
git sshd[7823]: error: Hm, kex protocol error: type 30 seq 1 [preauth]

The result is that all git related commands that involve the remote repo (fetch, push...) fail when using the GUI. They fail with the above error on server, but the SourceTree GUI keeps showing the progress bar with no extra output in the "Show Full Output" window. After a while, when the server drops the connection, this is the output
{code}
FATAL ERROR: Server unexpectedly closed network connection

fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.

Completed with errors, see above.
{code}

The same commands work fine through the terminal (git bash and windows cmd both work).

The git upgrade includes the following upgrades that sshd uses:
# upgraded libssh (0.6.5-1 -> 0.7.0-2)
# upgraded libssh2 (1.5.0-1 -> 1.6.0-1)
# upgraded openssh (6.8p1-2 -> 6.9p1-1)

By checking the openssh mailing lists I found this explanation for the type 30 error.
_> Hm, kex protocol error: type 30 seq 1 [preauth]_
_message type 30 is the pre-RFC4419 group exchange message.  Since RFC4419 was published nearly 10 years ago support for the non-standardized message was recently removed from OpenSSH._

If I understand this correctly, it seems that a newer key exchange method has to be used when connecting through SSH by using Putty/Plink with usernames and passwords.

UPDATE:
Using SSH keys fails with the same error as well.
SSH keys start working after updating the bundled /tools/putty/plink.exe. However connecting through SSH by using Putty/Plink with usernames and passwords still fails with the same error.
fields.summary: Git related commands stop working due to an error after upgrading git/openssh to 2.4.5/6.9p1-1

Also observed: If I go to the Log / History tab, whether the file is staged or not displays correctly.  Furthermore, if I return to the File Status tab, the display is correct.

fields.description:
Currently, SourceTree allows you to set a column guide for the commit message. This is helpful for keeping commit messages hard wrapped at line width. However, in practice we find that the length of the text recommended for the 'subject line' and 'body' of the commit message is different. For instance some practices recommend a subject line no longer than 50 characters and a body no longer than 72. 

It would be helpful if we could add a second guideline to the commit message input window so we set the recommended maximum length for both the subject and the body lines. An alternative may be to display the column number of the cursors position as you might find in a text editor.

It would be even better if SourceTree would automatically hard-wrap any text you wrote that exceeded the column guides so you needn't worry about column counting yourself. This ability is present in VIM and I have found that helpful for maintaining clean commit messages.
fields.summary: Allow multiple column guides in the commit message window to help keep the subject and body text lengths below a certain threshhold

fields.description:
When working with a large amount of items it's seldom a good idea to use a flat list... The ability to group those items is usually the way to go, and therefore the use of a tree is highly recommended.

That being said, it's exactly what could be improved in the Repository list of SourceTree. When working with a lot of repositories, SourceTree starts to become harder to use (and seems to me also slower). It would be so great to be able to create groups of repositories and close those groups when you don't need to access their content.

Refreshing also only displayed repositories would improve the responsiveness of the application and therefore the user experience.

SourceTree crashes on cloning new repository

fields.description:
The "Push changes immediately" option in the commit area does not default to origin.

Per @Steve Streeting, it should:
!http://i.imgur.com/1HzTLwH.png!

But, it doesn't:
!http://i.imgur.com/7L6B3Az.png!

The overall goal should be to be able to pull from upstream and push to origin via automation, but when the user has more than those two remotes, the automation breaks down, hence the bug is marked "Major".
fields.summary: "Push changes immediately" does not default to origin with multiple remotes while in "Push Branches: matching"

fields.description:
I'm working with a github repository that has a submodule and I don't have permissions to access the submodule repository.  Whenever I push/pull/etc Sourctree does "git -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false submodule update --init --recursive" which gives an error.

Please add a feature to disable this, ideally on a per-submodule basis.
fields.summary: Ignore submodule

fields.description:
SourceTree crashed when I was cloning multiple repositories.
For each one I clicked the "clone" button in bitbucket, and then selected "Clone in sourcetree".

After the crash I checked the contents of my repositories and all the files were downloaded correctly.
fields.summary: Crash when cloning multiple repositories

fields.description:
I use folders for grouping repositories by project or purpose. When i need move some repository between folders, I use simple drag and drop.
But problem is here - when I dragged repository, then every folder will open under cursor. It possible waits when mouse stays on folder for some time? For example 150 milliseconds?
fields.summary: Repository folders opens too fast

fields.description:
Submodule changes are shown by source tree even if the option "ignore = all" is set to a submodule. This is incorrect behaviour and seems to be unsupported.
You can read about this git feature on th eofficial documentation here http://git-scm.com/docs/gitmodules.
You can see a config file example at stackoverflow here
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3240881/git-can-i-suppress-listing-of-modified-content-dirty-submodule-entries-in-sta
fields.summary: Support ignoring submodule changes with ignore flags in git config
